INTRODUCTION

Dow Chemical Corporation has prepared this Risk Management Plan (RMP) Update for the Dow Chemical UCAR® Emulsion Systems plant in accordance with Section 2745.10 of the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.  In accordance with paragraph (a) of this section, the update has been prepared within 5 years of the date of the original submittal.  [The plan was last submitted to the Torrance Fire Department (the Administering Agency) in June 1999.]
The following activities were conducted in support of the RMP Update, in accordance with Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) RMP guidance for updates:

> A three year compliance audit was conducted by an outside environmental contractor, in accordance with Section 2760.8 of the CalARP regulations.
> The Offsite Consequence Analysis was revised using a current version of RMP*CompTM.  The affected population and list of sensitive receptors was revised using current population data and other resources.
> The seismic analysis for the affected systems was reviewed for changes to the system, changes to the building codes that may impact affected systems, and implementation of recommendations made in the last seismic review.

In addition, Dow Chemical has revised the Process Hazards Analysis (PHA) for the facility using a proprietary technique, and the external events analysis was expanded to include a qualitative evaluation of a variety of external events not previously discussed in the PHA.
The facility has changed ownership since the previous RMP was submitted and many of the various plans and programs referenced in the RMP have been revised.  Dow has prepared a new RMP registration submittal to reflect these changes to the RMP.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES 

Dow Chemical Corporation has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety.  Dow is committed to operating and maintaining all of the processes in a safe and responsible manner.  Dow has implemented

a combination of accident release prevention programs and emergency response planning progams to help ensure the safety of its employees and the public, as well as to protect the environment. These programs include both Dow Chemical's Responsible Care requirements and governmental requirements, such as EPA¿s RMP rule and the CalARP RMP requirements.

DESCRIPTION OF THE FACILITY AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES 

Dow Chemical Corporation, UCAR® Emulsion Systems, located in Torrance, California, operates a latex emulsion manufacturing facility that produces more than 100 million pounds of latex per year. The water-borne latex produced at this site is utilized by the coatings industry to make latex-based paints, caulks, adhesives and sealants. The facility is recognized as a covered source under the RMP rule as the facility maintains quantities of regulated substances listed in the RMP rule above the applicable thresholds. The UCAR® Emulsion Systems facility does not maintain specified quantities of any RMP regulated flammable substances, but does utilize the following RMP regulated toxic substances at levels above threshold limits: 

> Acrylonitrile (2-Propenenitrile) (CAS 108-05-4)
> Vinyl Acetate monomer (VAM) (Acetic Acid ethenyl ester) (CAS 107-13-1)

HAZARD ASSESSMENT

RMP regulations require that each facility identify worst-case and alternative release scenarios.  EPA has defined a worst-case release as the release of the entire contents of the largest vessel that contains a regulated substance in a 10-minute period.  EPA defines alternative release scenarios as scenarios that are more likely to occur than the worst-case scenario, and that reach an endpoint offsite, unless no such scenario exists.  One or more alternative release scenarios are evaluated to define the distance to the specified endpoint.  Unless otherwise specified, no credit was taken for administrative controls or active mitigation measures in evaluating the off-site impact of the scenarios.
Prediction

of the zone of potential impact for the worst-case and alternative releases was performed using RMP*Comp¿ (Version 1.07) released by EPA.  RMP*Comp¿ is an electronic tool to make the same calculations performed manually by following the procedures described in EPA¿s guidance document, RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance (April, 1999).  

Worst-Case Release Scenarios
VAM is not stored on the UCAR® facility but rather is fed by pipeline on an as-needed basis for batch processing during the manufacturer of latex.  Monomer mix tank number 4 (MMT-4) can hold the largest quantity of VAM, 4,500 gallons. The monomer mixing area is surrounded by a small dike sufficient to contain the contents of a spill of the maximum amount of VAM on-site in a monomer mixing tank.  The dike dimensions are approximately 50 feet by 50 feet by 4 inches deep.   Acrylonitrile is stored on-site in a 10,000-gallon storage tank.  Acrylonitrile is delivered to the facility by tanker truck with a nominal capacity of 5,600 gallons.  The acrylonitrile tank is located inside a 20 foot by 40 foot by 2 feet deep concrete containment area that can hold the contents of the tank plus freeboard for storm water and fire protection water. 
The worst-case release of VAM assumes the catastrophic failure of MMT-4 during a seismic event.  The worst-case meteorological conditions defined by EPA for the worst-case release are a wind speed of 1.5 meters per second (m/s) and a stability class of F (very stable).  For VAM, the worst-case distance to the threshold concentration of 0.26 mg/l is 0.7 miles (1,100 meters).
The worst-case release of acrylonitrile assumes the catastrophic failure of the acrylonitrile tank during a seismic event.  The worst-case acrylonitrile distance to the threshold concentration of 0.076 mg/l is also 0.7 miles (1,100 meters). 

Alternative-Release Scenarios
One alternative release scenario for acrylonitrile was assessed.  Acrylonitrile alternative scenario #1 consists of an unconfined

release from an open drain valve on the discharge side of a pump while transferring acrylonitrile to the mix tank.  The release is assumed to occur inside the spill containment area surrounding the monomer mix tanks. The alternative meteorological conditions defined by EPA for alternative releases are a wind speed of 3.0 meters per second (m/s) and a stability class of D (neutral). The distance to the acrylonitrile threshold concentration of 0.076 mg/l for alternative release scenario #1 is 0.2 miles (300 meters).
Two alternative release scenarios for VAM were assessed.  VAM alternative scenario #1 consists of an unconfined release from the three-inch pipeline from the Dow Torrance Distribution Terminal to the monomer mix tank area.  The distance to the threshold concentration of 0.26 mg/l is 0.2 miles (300 meters) for VAM alternative scenario #1.  VAM alternative scenario #2 assumes an open ¾-inch drain valve on the discharge side of a pump while transferring VAM to an intermediate mix tank.  The distance to the threshold for VAM alternative scenario 2 is 0.2 miles (300 meters).
A total of 7,100 persons in 2,650 households reside within the VAM and acrylonitrile worst-case impact distance, based on the 2000 Census data.  The sensitive receptors within 0.7 miles of the facility include schools, parks, and recreational areas.  Other potential receptors include industrial facilities and major commercial facilities.  For the alternative impact distance of 0.2 miles, there are no sensitive receptors.  The estimated population potentially effected by the alternative release scenario is an estimated 100 persons.  

Mitigation
The specific systems to prevent the worst-case release scenario of acrylonitrile from occurring, as well as mitigate its effects should they occur, include: 

> Hydrocarbon Gas Detector and Alarm Systems: This system is designed to detect toxic vapor releases and to automatically activate alarm systems to alert operations personnel of a possible eme

rgency situation. 
> Sprinkler Deluge System (water spray): This system is designed to mitigate and suppress toxic vapor clouds from migrating from the facility boundaries. 
> Inventory Restriction: Written operating procedures, which include an operating checklist, and a high- level shutdown system limits the maximum filling capacity of this storage tank to 84%. A high level alarm would sound if the tank were filled to 84% capacity. At this point, procedures require operations to stop all transfers into the tank. An additional high-high level alarm is set at 90%, which automatically stop all transfers into the tank.
> Reaction Prevention: Systems in place to ensure reactivity of material stored in tanks is inhibited. 
> Pressure Relief Systems: Pressure relief systems help to ensure that over-pressures within tanks are mitigated. 
> Operator Certification: Only trained and certified Dow Chemical employees are permitted to unload acrylonitrile into the storage tank. 
> Equipment Design and Construction: Design and construction codes & standards are met or exceeded. 
> Surveillance: Operations personnel routinely monitor the process and facility perimeters. 
The specific systems to prevent the alternative release scenario of acrylonitrile from occurring, as well as mitigate its effects should they occur, include: 
> Automated Containment Systems: A system is in place to automatically pump any releases in the spill containment area to a closed storage tank. This would mitigate the release of toxic material into the atmosphere. 
> Emergency Shutdown Systems: A manual emergency shutdown system is designed to shut down the pumps and put the transfer valves in a fail-safe position. 
> Hydrocarbon Gas Detector and Alarm Systems: This system is designed to detect toxic vapor releases and to automatically activate alarm systems to alert operations personnel of a possible emergency situation. 
> Sprinkler Deluge System (water spray): This system is designed to mitigate and su

ppress toxic vapor clouds from migrating from the facility boundaries. 
> Surveillance: Operations personnel routinely monitor the process and facility perimeters. 
The specific systems to prevent the worst-case and alternative release scenarios of VAM from occurring, as well as mitigate their effects should they occur, include: 
> Emergency Shutdown Systems: A manual emergency shutdown system is designed to shutdown the pumps and put the transfer valves in a fail-safe position. 
> Surveillance: Operations personnel routinely monitor the process and facility perimeters. 

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM 

The following is a summary of the general accident prevention program in place at Dow Chemical¿s UCAR® Emulsion Systems plant in Torrance.  Dow¿s general accident prevention program consists of compliance with the EPA and CalARP regulations as well as implementation of Dow Chemical's Operational Safety Program and Episodic Risk Management System.  Key elements include: 

Compliance Audits
In accordance with Section 2760.8 of the CalARP regulations, a three-year compliance audit was conducted by an outside environmental contractor, ENSR Corporation, using a modified EPA RMP audit protocol.  The audit report is included in Appendix E.  The audit findings noted the following deficiencies:

> The RMP lacked a Process Flow Diagram (PFD) for affected processes,
> The dates of the most recent revisions of the various plans and programs were not current,
> The facility contact information listed in the RMP registration documents was not current (due to change of ownership),
> The OCA required revisions due to changes in the risk evaluation model and the population density and location of sensitive receptors in the potential zone of impact from a worst-case release.

Each of these deficiencies has been addressed in this RMP Update.  The PFD is attached in Appendix A.  The revised OCA is attached in Appendix C and the dates of the plan revisions and facility co

ntact information are included in the registration included in Appendix F.
To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, Dow Chemical periodically conducts corporate and plant-led audits to ensure that process operations comply with governmental and Dow Chemical requirements.

Contractor Safety Program 
Dow Chemical uses contractors to supplement its work force during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities. Due to the fact that some contractors work on or near process equipment, the facility has procedures in place to ensure that contractors (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, (5) understand and follow site safety rules, and (6) inform facility personnel of any hazards that they might find during their work. 

Employee Participation 
Dow Chemical encourages employees to participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention. Employees have access to all information created as part of the facility accident prevention program. Specific ways that employees can be involved in the accident prevention program are documented in an employee participation plan that is maintained at the facility and addresses each accident prevention program element. In addition, employees participate in keeping process safety information up to date by making periodic inspections, having an active role in writing operating procedures and being involved in many other aspects of the accident prevention program, such as incident investigations. 

Episodic Risk Management System 
Periodic reviews are conducted to identify hazards that could have significant community impact and to recommend corrective action(s) needed to prevent their occurrence. These reviews utilize advanced quantitative risk assessment techniques. 

Equipment Design 
Vessels (including shi

pping containers) and other process equipment are designed according to recognized industry standards and/or governmental requirements. 
Incident Investigation 
Dow Chemical promptly investigates all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury. The goal of each investigation is to determine the root cause of the incident by reviewing facts and developing corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. 

Management of Change 
Dow Chemical has a comprehensive system to ensure that modified facilities and processes will be safe to operate. This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process operating conditions), procedures and other facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented. 

Mechanical Integrity 
Dow Chemical has well-established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition. The basic aspects of this program include: (1) conducting training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests, (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures. In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment. 

Operating Procedures 
Dow Chemical maintains written procedures that provide detail on how to safely operate a process, including various modes of process operations, such as unit startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, normal shutdown, and initial startup of a new process. These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators. These procedures are periodically reviewed

and annually certified as current and accurate. The procedures are maintained up-to-date by revising them as necessary.  In addition, the plant maintains specific procedures for maintaining process equipment so that it operates safely. The plant also trains persons who perform routine or complex maintenance tasks on process equipment. 
Operational Safety Program 
Dow Chemical has a comprehensive program to ensure that all the elements listed within this accidental release prevention program are implemented at every Dow Chemical location. This Program includes accountabilities for timely and proper implementation of the program elements. 

Operational Safety Standards 
Design requirements for active and passive mitigation controls used to prevent major process hazards are documented in operational safety standards. 

Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs) 
Dow Chemical conducts reviews just prior to startup to ensure that new and modified facilities and processes are safe for operation. A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves as a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented. 

Process Hazard Analysis
Dow conducted an internal audit of the UCAR® Emulsions Systems Torrance facility in 2002.  A PHA was conducted during the audit using Dow¿s proprietary ¿Reactive Chemical Process Hazard Analysis¿ (RCPHA).  RCPHA Software version 4.0 (Revised 1/10/01) was used in the review.  The staff performing the RCPHA were Joe Sokolik, Ron Weber, Don Eastepp, Pete Allen, Roger Graves, Erwin Morfe, and Al Fedoruk.  
The RCPHA methodology consists of a checklist designed by Dow for use in internal reactive chemical and PHA audits.  For each question in the questionnaire, there are columns for a yes/no/not applicable response, a response column, columns to check the work discipline affected, and an action item column.  In addition to the RCPHA questionnaire, there is a second questionn

aire that is used for field validation in conjunction with the RCPHA.
 
There have been no significant changes to vinyl acetate monomer and acrylonitrile processes at the UCAR® Emulsion Systems plant since the performance of the previous RMP and PHA. 
As part of the RMP Update, the RCPHA developed during the May 2002 audit was reviewed by ENSR for completeness and applicability.  There were no significant findings that were identified during the RCPHA or during ENSR¿s review of the RCPHA.  All action items established during the RCPHA audit have been assigned for follow-up by the Facility Manager.  Most items had a target completion data of December 31, 2003.  The remaining four items have a target completion date within the first half of 2004.  The final RCPHA report contained the following four comments:

1. The facility is well run with most process safety and reactive chemical issues suitably addressed.
2. The safety and loss prevention practices and requirements from the Union Carbide Corporation (UCC) organization remain in place and are being well followed.
3. There are differences in engineering practices between UCC and Dow that are being addressed on a prioritized basis.
4. There are a number of new Dow requirements that now apply to the UCAR® facility and a plan is in place to implement these new requirements

ENSR Corporation reviewed the seismic assessment portion of the Risk Management and Prevention Program (RMPP) (June 1999) prepared for the Union Carbide Emulsion Systems Facility.  After the review, ENSR conducted a walkthrough at the facility to confirm whether modifications recommended in the 1999 assessment had been completed.  

External Events Analysis
The 1999 RMPP seismic assessment of the facility estimated the seismic vulnerability of vessels, piping, and associated equipment and structures containing regulated substances (i.e. acrylonitrile and VAM).  In addition, vessels not containing regulated substances but which could impact vessels o

r piping containing regulated substances during a large earthquake were also evaluated.  The 1999 RMPP seismic review was performed according to the requirements in the 1998 Guidance for CalARP Seismic Assessment.  [The 1998 guidance is the current version of the guidance.]
Based on a review of the recommendations provided in the 1999 seismic assessment, and a walkthrough of the facility, it appears that all of the recommended modifications have not been adequately implemented.  The recommended modifications to the mixed monomer tanks and the power feed tank #3 have not been implemented as these units are scheduled to be removed at some unspecified date in the future.  However, the mixed monomer tanks and the power feed tank #3 are currently vulnerable to earthquake ground shaking and should be upgraded as previously recommended unless they are to be removed in the near future.

Process Safety Information 
Dow Chemical keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the processes. Chemical hazard, process technology, and equipment information is documented, maintained up-to-date and available to operating personnel. 
Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in material safety data sheets (MSDSs). For specific process areas, the facility has documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters (e.g., temperature, pressure and level control) in the Operational Safety Standard (OSS) documents. The facility ensures that the process is maintained within these limits using process controls and monitoring instruments, automated operating systems, highly trained personnel, and protective instrument system (i.e., automated shutdown systems). 
The facility maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment. This information, in combination with written procedures and train

ed personnel, provides a means for establishing inspection and maintenance activities. 

Safe Work Practices 
Dow Chemical has long-standing safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and process safety.  Examples of these include (1) control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel, (2) a lockout/tagout procedure to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance, (3) a procedure for safe removal of hazardous materials before process piping or equipment is opened, (4) a hot work permit and procedure to control spark-producing activities, and (5) a permit and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space. These procedures (and others), along with training of affected personnel, form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely. 

Training/Certification Programs 
To complement the written procedures for process operations, Dow Chemical has implemented a comprehensive training and certification program for all employees involved in operating a process. After employees demonstrate (e.g., through tests, skills demonstration) having adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they are certified to work independently.  In addition, trained technical staff is available 24 hours a day to support operations. 

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY 

In the last five years there has not been an accident or incident involving a release of either VAM or acrylonitrile from affected systems at the facility that resulted in an on-site death, injury, or property damage; or a known off-site death, injury, evacuation shelter-in-place, property damage or environmental damage. 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION 

The Dow Chemical facility maintains a written emergency response program to protect worker and public safety, as well as the environment. The program consists of procedures for responding to releases of hazardous sub

ional areas of concern identified during ENSR's walkthrough consisted of an overgrowth of vegetation at several locations, including along the VAM pipeline and within the containment area for the acrylonitrile storage tank.  The plant should establish a regular schedule for trimming and/or removing vegetation throughout the facility.

stances, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including: 

> Proper first-aid and medical treatment for exposures, 
> Evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation,
> Notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, 
> Post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements (if a release occurs), and 
> Inspecting, testing, maintaining, and using emergency response equipment. 

The emergency response program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to facility processes. Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties. 
The overall emergency response program for Dow Chemical in Torrance is coordinated with the Torrance Fire Department and the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). Dow Chemical conducts periodic emergency drills that involve the appropriate emergency response organizations. 
In addition, Dow Chemical's Hazardous Emergency Leaks Prevention (HELP) team located in Torrance responds to accidental releases from transportation incidents occurring in the continental U.S. 
The emergency response program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations. Detailed emergency response plans are developed and coordinated with the Torrance Fire Department. 

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY 

On-going programs, such as process hazard analysis reevaluations, continually aim to improve process safety. The following is a list of specific improvements that we are planning to implement at the UCAR® Emulsion Systems plant in Torrance to help prevent and/or better respond to accidental chemical releases: 
> Upgrade equipment and systems as specified by recent seismic assessment report conducted in May 1999 and revalidated in November 2003.
